A cult of guns leads to deadly 
 October 14, 2009 
 "Guns don't kill people, people kill people."
 
 Problem is, people with guns ready at hand sometimes use guns as a way to resolve problems. Witness last week's domestic tragedy involving the gun-toting soccer mom from Lebanon whose husband shot her to death, then turned his gun on himself. Two parents dead, three young children, 2, 6 and 10, orphaned.
 
 Police: Gun-toting soccer mom was shot by husband during video chat Gun-toting Pa. soccer mom, husband found shot dead Maybe a gunless 33-year-old Scott Hain would have found another way to kill his 31-year-old wife, Meleanie. But certainly the parents had made something of a cult of guns in their lives. Meleanie became notorious a year ago when she openly carried a loaded pistol to her daughter's soccer game. The county sheriff revoked her concealed carry permit, saying her provocative behavior indicated she was using poor judgment. But she appealed and a judge gave her the permit back, ordering her to conceal the weapon. She later sued the sheriff, blaming him for decimating her child care business. Maybe she couldn't get her thoughts around the possibility that other parents simply didn't want their young children around accessible guns.
 
 Other indications of the couple's reverence for guns surfaced. Meleanie Hain also wore her 9 mm Glock pistol to the grocery store. A family car's bumper sticker said "NRA law enforcement."
 
 And neighbors recently spotted Meleanie holding a rifle while she chatted with someone outside her house.
 
 The Second Amendment confers the right to bear arms, and earlier this year a U.S. Supreme Court ruling curtailed government's ability to regulate guns. Americans clearly revel in their ability to own and use firearms of all types.
 
 But besides any firearm's inherent danger, there's human psychology to consider. Despite a commonly held belief, owning a gun does not make people safer. In fact statistics say otherwise. And when people's lives begin to revolve around guns, it's inevitable that guns will be at hand at moments of anger or danger. Did anyone feel safer during the summer's town hall meetings when gun owners showed up carrying a weapon? Isn't the whole idea of a town meeting a conversation, not dispute by arms?
 
 Neighbors said the Hains had been having marital problems. A gun ended the parents' conflict. But that gun took a mother and father away from three innocent children forever.
 
 The National Rifle Association is highly effective at motivating gun owners to protect their right to bear arms. The NRA's lobbying success in not only defending but expanding gun rights is well known.
 
 The NRA ought to throw an equal amount of energy into reminding members that guns are best used for hunting and target practice, not for brandishing at public events or for threatening spouses. Some people need such reminders, and often.
 
 There's a better way to teach Americans the meaning of the hallowed right to bear arms than by encouraging a fetish.
